newsitem.title: NORWAY: Cruise liner Hanseatic free of sandbank.
newsitem.headline: Cruise liner Hanseatic free of sandbank.

text.p: Elderly passengers stranded for four days aboard a grounded cruise liner in the Arctic were temporarily evacuated to a rescue ship on Thursday, an official said.
The 145 people, mostly German and with an average age of 70, were taken off shortly before their liner, The Hanseatic, was refloated.
They were later allowed back on board.
The German-owned cruiser had been stuck on a sandbank off the Norwegian Arctic island of Spitzbergen since Sunday. Efforts to pull her free had been hampered by drifting ice.
Elisabeth Aarsaether, spokeswoman for the governor's office at Longyear on Spitzbergen, said the 9,000 deadweight-ton liner, was freed at 3.45 a.m. (0145 gmt) by the coastguard ship Tromsoe.
"We had a deadline until 4 a.m. when the high water would be gone," she told Norwegian radio.
Officials said all 145 passengers were evacuated to the Tromsoe a few hours before the liner, with a crew of 115, was pulled free.
They said the passengers were let on board the Hanseatic again after an inspection showed the navigational instruments were in order and that the hull was not leaking.

"There are no problems with the ship or the passengers," a spokesman for the governor's office said. "Divers are checking the hull a bit closer now. The Hanseatic may sail for Longyear in the afternoon."
The passengers were expected to arrive late on Thursday or early Friday in Longyear, where they would be put on a charter flight to Hamburg.
Coastguards unloaded the ship's 480 tonnes of heavy fuel oil before dragging her free.

The ship's owner, Hamburg-based Hapag-Lloyd AG, had originally planned to start evacuating passengers at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), but the wind changed late on Wednesday and pushed away the icefloes massed around the liner.
